ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I thought I was knowledgeable about the world and climate change. This class, however, exposed me to so much more. Learning about everything from Hippocrates to the Marshall Islands was an incredible experience.

Dove's readings were well chosen, with the exception of Jared Diamond. The format of the class was generally useful, though could be set up in a way to encourage additional leadership in group discussion. My suggestion is for Dove to pause in his lectures and deliberately call for discussion by asking questions and allowing students to ask questions of other students. I say this because often the juice of the discussion would come out at the end of the class period, and begin to heat up just in time for class to be over.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Dr. Dove and his deep knowledge of the material.

Spending a lot of time with the readings- many classes use readings to support class material. But this class was great because we read the readings on our own, wrote commentary on our own, re-processed the readings through the brain of Dove, read the thoughts of our brilliant classmates on the readings, and then discussed them in class. Such a luxury.
Discussions in class, the recommended readings

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: None.

My suggestion is to have more bench marks for the final paper. I will take ownership of this critique; as a student looking at this in retrospect I could have been much more proactive in tackling the final paper. But on a course level, it would be good to have the proposal as the first bench mark assignment, a first outline (or lit review?) as the second bench mark assignment, along with a (strongly suggested) office hours check in at that point, before Thanksgiving break. From that point on, students should know to have a first draft written by two weeks out.

If students are going to be asked to write response essays, then the instructor should actually save time in class for discussion/presentation of those essays. He should also read and comment on them - ideally prior to writing other essays, so that we could learn from our work.
More structured discussion. Longer discussion. More clarity among students of what specific terms mean

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It provided a great baseline on which to build my dissertation.

We often get stuck in a single way of seeing the world, of organizing knowledge, and of evaluating truth/reality. At FES, this way is primarily oriented toward Western science, economics, (post-colonial) sustainable resource management, expertise, and power. We are often unable to check our own assumptions about the world because we are surrounded by those who either don't encourage us to question the status-quo, or those who haven't taken the time to read anything outside (or even tangential to) their discipline in years. This course challenges the assumption that there is only one way of knowing climate change, the topic(s) that so many of us are interested in. This alone makes it worth your time -- as does taking a class with Susan Clark.
Important for understanding debates on climate change. the anthropological view gives a more nuanced and complex overview of the problems and history of the anthropocene

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to know more about the world and how climate change is going to affect everyone. It's not going away, so learning as much as a can is important.
Because of the professor's expertise on this subject

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: This may have been an interesting idea, to have a group assignment. I could see it being an assignment to lead with one other person a class discussion, or to have a feedback session around the final paper with one other classmate.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be prepared to read. Enjoy every minute of learning from Dr. Dove.
Keep up with the readings, read your classmates' commentaries, and be constantly thinking about how the readings fit into your final paper. Go to office hours early regarding your final paper.
Do all of the reading closely. Some of it is tedious, but it is all necessary to be able to fully gather the importance of what Dove says in class. You can't just float by on this one.
Choose your paper topic and do the readings with them in mind. Read the Recommended readings! That is where the meat of the ideas are and they are all excellent!!!
